TopicTitle: Devnote Tuesdays: The "Progress is Progressing Progressively" Edition

Articles.Content:
From what I could hear there aren't really that many new details about future updates in the kerbalcast. It's implied that the Admin Building will allow the player to be able to exchange between funds, science and reputation, but that has been mentioned before. Apparently that's just the tip of the iceberg, but MaxMaps doesn't say more.

He does confirm that crew movement between parts will be done via a menu, and says that Squad still plans to improve the fuel transfer system. He lets it slip that the artists are working on about 50 very large new 3d models - maybe the new feature that's coming after .25 will be cities and buildings around kerbin, or perhaps a more customizable KSC, with several building options and a sense of progression (I'm just guessing).

On a side note, new versions of KSP arrive about every 8 to 10 weeks. So, who knows, we may have 0.25 around 1 October. That would be nice. May be by mid-September, a few more hard details will emerge concerning the Administration building and screenshots of the new/re-done parts to whet the appetite. Depends upon what Rowsdower can pry out of Felipe et al.

My guess for the "you won't see it if you play well enough" feature would be loans for when your program goes into the red. Not particularly exciting, but Squad seems to be making a habit these days out of hyping up what turn out to be underwhelming announcements

As for the "resource" conversion, dang, I was really hoping they'd ditch that idea. Funds, science, and rep are so easy to come by that being able to convert one to the other will only serve to water down the career mode design further when it's already swimming in its own fluids IMO.

Not sure what the point is of having three individual values for stuff you're just going to be able to convert from one to the other. May as well bundle it all into one uber resource and call it a day.

It does seem like it would render having three currencies kinda pointless if you can convert between them. Trying to balance this out with poor conversion rates would just lead to converting just not being worth it at all. Why do science if you can just grind a bunch of contracts that give you science anyway to get cash to buy science with? Just further making the entire science system something to be ignored by the player.

And if they are going to include loans for going into the red, how lenient is that going to be? Because there's a point where it just renders the concept of money as a limiting factor useless because you can just build whatever, go into the red and take out a loan. Or take out a loan to cover the loan you've already taken out. If someone isn't capable of playing within the boundaries of the money system, they should not be able to ignore that system, and should probably be given a game over notice. There is already a separate science mode for those that want to play career but don't want monetary limits.

Not sure what the point is of having three individual values for stuff you're just going to be able to convert from one to the other. May as well bundle it all into one uber resource and call it a day.

Depends on if lossy exchange rates are used. If you pay a penalty for each conversion, players will only do it when they really need it. Like if you just need a little more science to unlock that next node, or a few thousand kerbucks to launch that mission you spent an hour or two building.

I'm inclined to wait and see how it works before writing the feature off.

Yup, it would be extremely tricky to balance so that it's useful without nullifying the value of having three resources. IMO, the number of different variables that Squad is building in that they'll need to balance around is getting rather insane, and so far, there isn't really any balance to speak of in career mode so it looks like they're making a tough job even harder for themselves by including additional stuff along these lines.

With the last release and the science built into contracts, actual experiments largely lost all meaning because science points just fall out of the trees while you're doing contracts. Reputation doesn't have any tangible meaning. Funds become irrelevant within a couple of contracts. So, already the values in question have very little meaning.

IMO, then allowing conversion between what are already extremely ambiguous values in terms of their impact on gameplay that are extremely easy to come by is rather dangerous, and like I said, seems to only serve to further water down the design.

I'm really not sure if anyone out there really feels the need for this kind of conversion, but I would be really surprised if anybody was looking forward to it as something that will improve the game for them. Kinda just seems like a "just because" feature that doesn't seem to have a sound gameplay justification behind it.

If you pay a penalty for each conversion, players will only do it when they really need it.

I guess, but that seems to be operating under the assumption that players will ever really need to do anything to advance. From what I've seen with regards to Squad's statements on design direction in the past, it sounds like they don't want to "force" the player to do anything at any point, and view career as just sandbox with a few bells and whistles where doing absolutely anything at all leads to advancement.

So, in a world where you can do stuff like just hop out of your capsule to collect samples on the launchpad, or drive around the space center doing "science", or perform 'hit space bar and we'll pay you!' surface part-testing contracts, I really doubt the player will ever run into a situation where they "need" to do anything.

A very short and quick overview of the game would be sufficient really to point new players where to go and look for things, I agree here.

For anything else I will wait and see what the difficulty settings will be.

For anything else I will wait and see what the difficulty settings will be.

The difficulty settings give me pause. As much as I love challenge and think KSP is sorely missing it, the ones mentioned with regards to not being able to revert or quicksave don't strike me as in any way practical.

Now granted, hopefully this will eventually not be the case, but for now KSP is just way too unstable for those to be reasonable options for increasing difficulty. As long as the Kraken continues to attack on a regular basis and other bugs are just as likely to result in mission failure as it happening due to player error, I can't see such options being anything but an exercise in frustration.

IMO a rogue-like (and that's what those options kinda strike me as) needs to be even more stable than your average game to prevent situations where hours of gameplay are lost through no fault of the player.

I certainly hope KSP will be there one day, but I sincerely doubt anyone that plays it much would argue it's there already.
